sections.title: What is Time-Based Movement?
sections.content: Time-based movement means controlling the robot by running motors for a set amount of time. This is the simplest way to make your robot move in autonomous mode. gm0: Time-Based Autonomous FTC Docs: Time-Based Autonomous

sections.title: Implementing Time-Based Movement
sections.content: To move the robot for a specific time, set the motor power, use sleep(), then stop the motors. Break your code into small, testable segments. gm0: Example OpMode

sections.title: Limitations of Time-Based Control
sections.content: Time-based movement can be unreliable because battery voltage, friction, and field conditions affect how far the robot moves. Use this method for simple tasks or as a backup. gm0: Limitations of Time-Based Autonomous

sections.title: When to Use Time-Based Movement
sections.content: Time-based movement is best for simple autonomous tasks, backup plans, or when you don't need high precision. FTC Docs: When to Use Time-Based Autonomous

sections.title: Best Practices and Troubleshooting
sections.content: Tune your timings by testing on the field. Use telemetry to debug. If the robot moves too far or not far enough, adjust the power or time. gm0: Troubleshooting Time-Based Autonomous

sections.title: Time-Based Movement Practice
tasks: Write a routine that drives forward, turns, and drives backward using only time-based movement.
Test your routine on the field and adjust the timing for accuracy.
Add telemetry to display which action is running.
Experiment with different power levels and observe the effect.
Document your findings and share with your team.
